﻿﻿﻿Abdominal aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Supine vena cava syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supine vena cava syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates supine hypotension syndrome, also known as supine vena cava syndrome. This condition occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava (IVC) while the woman is in a supine position. This compression leads to reduced venous return to the heart, causing hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope. It is especially dangerous during cesarean sections, as spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension. To prevent this, a wedge is placed beneath the right hip during the procedure to tilt the patient slightly to the left, thereby relieving pressure on the vena cava.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ascending aorta syndrome: This condition is not typically associated with pregnancy and does not involve the pressure of the gravid uterus on the IVC.

 

Option B. Superior vena-caval syndrome: This syndrome involves obstruction of the superior vena cava, leading to symptoms such as facial swelling and dyspnea. It is unrelated to the position of a pregnant woman and the compression of the IVC.

 

Option C. Abdominal aorta syndrome: There is no specific syndrome by this name. The abdominal aorta may be compressed during pregnancy, but it does not lead to the symptoms associated with supine hypotension syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine vena cava syndrome occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava when the woman is in a supine position, leading to hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.

 

Ref: Page no 2237, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia undergoes prophylactic irradiation prior to autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Which of the following will be the least affected? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Neurons

 

Explanation:

 

Neurons (Central nervous system) are the least affected by irradiation among the options given, due to their highly differentiated and non-dividing nature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Spermatogonia: These are germ cells that continually divide and are highly sensitive to radiation, which can lead to infertility.

 

Option. B. Intestinal epithelial cells: These cells have a high turnover rate, making them very sensitive to radiation, which can result in gastrointestinal toxicity.

 

Option. D. Bone marrow/erythroid precursor cells: These cells are among the most sensitive to radiation due to their role in rapidly producing new blood cells, leading to potential marrow suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: DNA packing is done by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histone

 

Histones are proteins responsible for DNA packaging. The DNA wraps around histones, forming a structure called a nucleosome. Histones are positively charged proteins that interact with the negatively charged DNA, allowing for efficient packaging and compaction of DNA strands. This packaging is essential for the organization of DNA within the cell nucleus and its regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycoprotein: Glycoproteins are not directly involved in DNA packaging. They are molecules composed of a protein and a carbohydrate moiety. While glycoproteins have various functions in the cell, they do not play a role in the compaction and organization of DNA.

 

Option C. Nucleic acid: DNA itself is a type of nucleic acid. DNA molecules are composed of nucleotides and serve as the genetic material of cells. DNA molecules do not package themselves; instead, they interact with histones and other proteins to undergo packaging and compaction.

 

Option D. Helicases: Helicases are enzymes responsible for unwinding and separating the DNA strands during processes such as DNA replication and transcription. They do not participate in DNA packaging; instead, their role is to facilitate the access of various cellular machinery to the DNA template.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleosomes = DNA + Histone proteins

 

Histone proteins are rich in basic AA such as lysine and arginine, so, carry a positive charge. While DNA due to PO42- groups has large negative charge. So, in nucleosomes, DNA and histones are tightly packed due to interaction between these opposite charges.

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 351

questions.text: A female presented with an ulcerated breast lump. Nipple retraction was seen, with some warmth and redness. On biopsy, it was diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma. According to AJCC 8th Ed., which of these correctly represents the stage? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T4b

 

In the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) 8th edition staging system, the classification of breast cancer stages is detailed based on tumor size, lymph node involvement, and the presence of metastasis.

 

The presentation of an ulcerated breast lump, nipple retraction, warmth, and redness suggests skin involvement, which is characteristic of a T4 classification. Specifically, the presence of ulceration and skin involvement corresponds to T4b. T4b is used when there is skin involvement in the form of ulceration, satellite skin nodules, or peau d’orange (skin changes resembling the texture of an orange).

 

While there is the possibility of inflammatory breast cancer due to the warmth and redness, the key feature here is ulceration, which is more indicative of T4b. Inflammatory breast cancer would correspond to a T4d classification, characterized by more extensive skin changes like diffuse erythema and edema (peau d'orange) involving more than one-third of the breast, often with underlying invasive ductal carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IV with N1-N2 involvement: This is incorrect as there is no evidence of distant metastasis (M1), which is required for a Stage IV classification. The presence of regional lymph node involvement (N1-N2) alone does not justify a Stage IV classification.

 

Option C. Stage IIIB: This could be considered if the case were inflammatory breast cancer, but based on the ulceration and other features described, T4b is more appropriate unless additional evidence of inflammatory changes was present.

 

Option D. It cannot be M1: This statement is partially correct as the case does not mention any distant metastasis (M1), but it doesn’t address the primary tumor stage, which is the focus of the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulceration of a breast lump with skin involvement typically corresponds to T4b in the AJCC 8th edition staging system for breast cancer. It is essential to differentiate between T4b and T4d (inflammatory breast cancer) based on the clinical presentation and pathological findings.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient presents with weight loss, anxiety, tachycardia, and restlessness. The resting pulse was 110 beats per minute. Which of the following tests should be done next to evaluate her condition further? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TSH

 

Explanation:

 

In the evaluation of suspected thyroid dysfunction, the initial and most crucial test is the measurement of Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH). TSH is the most sensitive indicator of thyroid function because even minor changes in thyroid hormone levels cause significant changes in TSH levels due to the feedback mechanism between the thyroid gland and the pituitary gland. Elevated or suppressed TSH levels provide clear insight into whether the thyroid gland is underactive (hypothyroidism) or overactive (hyperthyroidism). Given the patient's symptoms of weight loss, anxiety, tachycardia, and restlessness, hyperthyroidism is suspected, making TSH the appropriate initial test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Total T3: T3 levels can be influenced by various factors and are usually measured after initial TSH and Free T4 tests suggest hyperthyroidism.

 

Option B.  Thyroid Scan: This imaging test evaluates thyroid structure and function, useful in cases where nodules or hyperactivity need to be assessed. It is not the first-line test for evaluating general thyroid function.

 

Option C. Free T4: Free T4 is important in assessing thyroid function and is typically measured alongside TSH. However, TSH is preferred as the initial screening test due to its sensitivity in detecting thyroid dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial test for evaluating suspected thyroid dysfunction, particularly in hyperthyroid symptoms, is TSH due to its sensitivity and reliability in reflecting thyroid status.

questions.text: Which of these structures are retained during radical neck dissection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sublingual gland

 

In a radical neck dissection, the aim is to remove extensive lymphatic tissue potentially involved with malignancies, but the procedure generally spares certain non-lymphatic structures unless directly involved by the tumor. The sublingual gland, which is located under the floor of the mouth, is not typically removed during a radical neck dissection because it is not within the field of the lymph node groups that are typically excised. This gland remains intact unless the specific tumor pathology dictates otherwise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tail of parotid: The tail of the parotid may be removed if it is involved with the tumor or if the dissection needs to be extended to ensure comprehensive removal of cancerous tissues.

 

Option C. Submandibular gland: This gland is typically removed during radical neck dissections because it lies within the Level I lymph nodes, which are included in the dissection.

 

Option D. Level 2b lymph nodes: These are generally removed in a radical neck dissection, which traditionally includes the removal of lymph nodes from Levels I to V.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition Page No. 442; Stell and Maran 5th edition Page No. 710

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:(NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ureterocele

 

Explanation:

 

  • The IVP shows bilateral cobra head or adder head sign/ cobra head appearance. It describes the cystic dilation of the distal end of ureter.
  • It may be simple (like in this case where it is located at the VUJ) or may be ectopic in location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Horse shoe kidney: Characterized by a "hand-shake" or "flower vase" sign due to the fusion of the kidneys across the midline, typically seen in the lower lumbar region. This appearance does not match the image shown.

 

 

Option C. Retroperitoneal fibrosis: Often causes medial deviation of the ureters or a "silent kidney" if severe obstruction occurs. Not relevant to the observed sign.

 

 

Option D. Posterior urethral valve: Affects male infants primarily and involves obstruction within the posterior urethra, leading to bladder and kidney changes. It does not cause the "cobra head" appearance seen here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureterocele should be suspected when an IVP reveals a "cobra head" sign, representing cystic dilation of the distal ureter. This condition can affect urinary drainage and lead to complications, requiring timely diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Identify the marked ligament?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCL

 

In the image, the arrow points to a structure consistent with the location and orientation of the PCL. The PCL  attaches to the posterior tibial condyle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACL (Anterior Cruciate Ligament): The ACL, crosses in the middle of the knee with the PCL but is positioned anteriorly on the tibia.

 

Option C. Meniscus: They are located throughout the articular surface of knee joint

 

Educational Objective :

 

The marked ligament in the MRI scan is the PCL (Posterior Cruciate Ligament). This identification is supported by the ligament's location and trajectory as depicted in the image.

questions.text: An old man presents with dyspnea and swelling of his feet. On examination, rales are heard and he is found to have an enlarged heart on chest x-ray. Which of the following will delay the progression?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Captopril

 

Explanation:

 

Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, has been shown to improve survival and delay the progression of heart failure. ACE inhibitors like Captopril work by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, leading to vasodilation and reduced workload on the heart. This class of drugs is considered a cornerstone in the management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HF-REF). The benefits of ACE inhibitors in heart failure are well-documented, including the 1992 study on Enalapril, which demonstrated its effectiveness as a gold standard treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: A loop diuretic, Furosemide is effective in reducing symptoms of congestion and decreasing heart failure hospitalization rates but does not improve survival or delay disease progression.

 

Option B. Carvedilol: While Carvedilol, a non-selective beta-blocker, has mortality benefits and improves survival in heart failure patients, it is not preferred over ACE inhibitors as the first choice for delaying heart failure progression.

 

Option C. Digoxin: This medication can reduce symptoms and heart failure hospitalizations to some extent, particularly in advanced heart failure, but it does not delay disease progression or improve survival, as evidenced by trials like the DIG trial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors, such as Captopril, are essential in delaying the progression of heart failure and improving survival.

questions.text: Match the following tumours with their treatment choices: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d

 

 

1. GIANT CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Radiological features: Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with  hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

2. OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.
    • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic  bone may be seen outside the involved bone.
       
  • Management:
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.
       

3. SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Simple bone cysts are a common pseudotumor of bone.
  • They are found in the proximal humerus in 50% of cases and in the upper femur in 25%.
  • The calcaneus and pelvis are also uniquely common locations.
  • Patients are asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • Radiographs typically show a solitary cyst that is centrally located in the metaphyseal area and has marked thinning of the adjacent cortical bone and a pseudoloculated appearance.
  • If there is associated fracture, radiographs may show the characteristic “fallen leaf” sign.
  • In weight-bearing bones, such as the proximal femur, lesions should be treated aggressively.
  • Management:
    • Initial management usually involves aspiration/injection with either bone marrow or corticosteroid.
    • The injections are carried out with bone biopsy needles and are repeated three to five times at intervals of 2 to 3 months, depending on the radiographic response.
    • Curettage and bone grafting may also be an effective modality.

 

4. OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • The most common benign osteoid-forming tumor is the osteoid osteoma, accounting for 10% of all benign bone tumors.
  • The proximal femur is the most common location.
  • Dull, aching, nocturnal pain is characteristic, and it is commonly relieved entirely by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) secondary to a high concentration of prostaglandins in the nidus.
  • Radiographic Feature:
    • Central, lytic nidus usually 1 cm or less in diameter. The more common cortically-based lesion exhibits extensive reactive sclerosis, creating a fusiform bulge on the bone surface. If the nidus is close to, or actually in, a joint, as in a femoral neck lesion, the resulting reactive synovitis may mimic a pyarthrosis or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Technetium bone scans are invariably positive. A CT scan is recommended to better anatomically locate the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
    • In the spine, the typical location for an osteoid osteoma is in the posterior elements.
       
  • Management:
    • Many cases of osteoid osteoma are stage 1 lesions and can be treated symptomatically with aspirin or NSAIDs until they spontaneously resolve. If the patient fails such treatment, intervention is warranted.
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation has emerged as the preferred treatment modality in many cases.
    • If open surgical excision is undertaken, the entire nidus must be eradicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Klumpke’s palsy?(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Claw hand

 

  • Klumpke’s palsy is the lower brachial plexus injury involving C8 and T1 nerve roots.
  • It is less common, but more severe.
  • It involves weakness of wrist and finger flexors and the intrinsic hand muscles.
  • Sensation is lost on ulnar side of the forearm.
  • There may also be vasomotor impairment and unilateral Horner’s syndrome.
  • Claw hand deformity is the usual outcome.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wrist drop. The radial nerve is responsible for innervating the extensor muscles of the wrist and digits. Consequently, injury to the radial nerve results in the inability to properly utilize these extensor muscles. As a result, the hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position. This is known as wrist drop.

 

 

Option B. Ape thumb deformity. Ape thumb deformity is a condition in which the thumb is permanently rotated and adducted, resulting in a loss of its opposable function. This deformity is caused by damage to the distal median nerve, which supplies the muscles that control the thumb. The thumb may also experience limited flexion and extension.

 

 

Option D. Porter’s tip deformity. Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (mainly C5, partially C6) causes Erb's Paralysis. This causes paralysis of biceps, deltoid, brachialis and brachioradialis mainly; and supraspinatus, infraspinatus, supinator partially. The muscle paralysis causes the arm to hang by the side in adduction and medial rotation with forearm extended and pronated. This deformity is called as “policeman’s tip” or “porter’s tip hand”.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The characteristic deformity of Klumpke’s palsy is Claw hand due to paralysis of intrinsic hand muscles and weakness of wrist and finger flexors.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant

questions.text: A woman has been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Choose the correct statement? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

 

The amount of radiation exposure follows Inverse Square law which states that the radiation Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Small blood vessels are radiosensitive.

 

Option C: Cancer cells are rapidly proliferating cells are most radiosensitive.

 

Option D: Bone marrow, gonads, bowel mucosa possess high radiosensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Inverse Square Law is critical to understanding radiation dosage and safety in radiotherapy, ensuring that radiation exposure is managed correctly to maximize the therapeutic effect while minimizing harm to healthy tissues. This principle helps in planning and delivering radiation treatments effectively.

questions.text: The life cycle of an organism is given below. Identify the vector involved? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trombiculid mite

 

The above picture shows the life cycle of trombiculid mite.

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium, is the causative agent of scrub typhus, a vector-borne disease transmitted by infected chiggers (trombiculid mite larvae).

 

Host: A number of small rodents particularly wild rats of subgenus Rattus are the natural hosts for scrub typhus

 

The incubation period of scrub typhus is about 6 to 21 days

 

The infection is transmitted to man and rodents by some species of infective trombiculid mites.

 

Once, the mite is infected in nature by feeding on the body fluid of small mammals, including the rodents, they maintain the infection throughout their life stages and, as adults, pass the infection on to their eggs in a process called transovarial transmission. Similarly, the infection passes from the egg to the larva or adult in a process called transstadial transmission. In this way, chigger mite populations can autonomously maintain their infectivity over long periods of time.

 

A large number of the Orientia tsutsugamushi are present in the salivary glands of the larvae and these are injected into its host when it feeds. The bite of the mite leaves a characteristic black eschar that is useful to the doctor for making the diagnosis.

 

Human infection takes place when man accidentally picks up an infective larval mite while walking, sitting, or lying on the infested ground.

 

The adult mites have a four-stage lifecycle: egg, larva, nymph and adult.

 

The larva is the only stage (chigger) that can transmit the disease to humans and other vertebrates, since the other life stages (nymph and adult) do not feed on vertebrate animals. Both the nymph and the adult are free-living in the soil.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hard tick: Hard ticks, such as Ixodes species, are vectors for diseases like Lyme disease and are not involved in the life cycle shown in the image.

 

Option B. Soft tick: Soft ticks, like Ornithodoros species, are vectors for diseases such as tick-borne relapsing fever, but are not depicted in the life cycle in the image.

 

Option D. Louse: Lice are vectors for diseases like epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, and are not involved in the life cycle shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective

 

The trombiculid mite, particularly its larval stage (chigger), is the vector for scrub typhus, transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi to humans and rodents through its bite, which leaves a characteristic black eschar.

questions.text: A female presented in dermatology OPD with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best step among the following options? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Evaluate for hyperandrogenism

 

  • Since the patient is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy, syndromes associated with acne should be evaluated and ruled out to reach a diagnosis. One of the important syndrome is HAIR-AN syndrome.
  • Hence, the next best step would be to evaluate for hyperandrogenism.

 

Important Syndromes Associated with Acne:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Looking for dietary triggers: It could be considered, but this should already be taken care of before prescribing isotretinoin and antibiotics.

 

Option C. Checking for antibiotic resistance: This seems an appropriate step but can’t prioritize over ruling out HAIR-AN syndrome in this patient.

 

Option D. Drug triggers are unlikely to be the primary cause of acne patient who is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics. Moreover, lesions in Drug-induced acne are monomorphic and comedones are absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When faced with a female patient whose acne has not improved with oral isotretinoin and antibiotics, the next best step is to evaluate for hyperandrogenism, which can point to an underlying hormonal cause such as PCOS, necessitating a different treatment approach.

 

References: Williams Gynaecology 4th edition: page no 392-394

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Targeted biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

A targeted biopsy (punch biopsy) is the next line of management in the above case as the patient is symptomatic (postcoital bleeding) and has a visible lesion. The biopsy will help in diagnosing the nature of the lesion, which is crucial for further management.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Conization: Conization is an excisional procedure done once biopsy-proven intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 and 3) is diagnosed. It is not the initial step when a visible lesion is present and needs to be assessed.

 

Option B. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure done for CIN 1 or 2. It is not suitable for a visible lesion with postcoital bleeding without a prior biopsy.

 

Option D. Pap smear: Pap smear is done when there are symptoms with no identifiable lesion. In the presence of a visible mass, a direct biopsy is more appropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a symptomatic patient with postcoital bleeding and a visible lesion on the cervix, the next step is a targeted biopsy to diagnose the nature of the lesion.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg662, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg345

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cervical Rib

 

Explanation :

 

Cervical Ribs

 

Cervical ribs are supernumerary or accessory ribs arising from the seventh cervical vertebra.

C/F:  Usually asymptomatic, they are the most important anatomic rib variant clinically, because they can cause thoracic outlet syndrome by compression of the brachial plexus or subclavian vessels.

Thoracic outlet syndrome: Most commonly-C8, T1 roots compression

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Costochondritis: Involves inflammation of the rib cage's cartilage, particularly where the upper ribs attach to the sternum, an area not visible as an anomaly on X-rays.

 

Option C. Rib Fracture 2nd / 3rd: Would show discontinuity or displacement of the rib bones, which is not evident here.

 

Option D. C5/C6 Spondylolisthesis: Pertains to the displacement of one of the spinal vertebra in relation to another, typically seen in the neck's vertebral column, not visible on this thoracic X-ray.

 

Educational Objective :


Cervical ribs are supernumerary ribs that can cause complications such as thoracic outlet syndrome due to their position and potential to compress nearby nerves and blood vessels.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with motor traffic accident with BP 90/60mm Hg. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechia were seen. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. eFAST

 

Explanation:

 

The next step in the evaluation of a trauma patient with the given findings is the Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST). This non-invasive imaging technique is crucial for rapidly identifying free fluid and organ injuries in the abdomen, as well as potential pneumothorax or hemothorax, which are critical in trauma cases. eFAST is used to quickly assess both stable and unstable patients following blunt abdominal trauma, providing immediate information that can dictate further management steps.

 

Details:

 

eFAST Role: This ultrasound examination checks for free intraperitoneal or pericardial fluid and can evaluate the integrity of the pleural spaces.

 

Stability: Despite the patient's low blood pressure, he is neurologically intact (GCS 15/15) and responsive, which allows for an ultrasound examination before more invasive procedures are considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exploratory laparotomy: Generally reserved for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability after eFAST or when eFAST is positive for intra-abdominal injury needing surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Intubation: Might be necessary if respiratory status worsens or if advanced airway management is required, but the patient’s current stable neurological status does not immediately warrant this.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan): Used after eFAST if the patient remains hemodynamically stable and further detailed evaluation of internal injuries is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for 8 months. A barium swallow was done and is shown in the image below. What other investigations should be done to confirm the diagnosis in this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) UGIE + manometry

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario and the barium swallow image show a bird beak sign which indicates achalasia cardia. To confirm the diagnosis, Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and manometry should be performed. Manometry is the IOC for achalasia cardia and other motility disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. UGIE + contrast enhanced CT: While useful for structural evaluation, it does not specifically assess esophageal motility.

 

Option B. UGIE + PET: Typically used for oncological assessments, not directly useful for diagnosing motility disorders.

 

Option C. UGIE + 24-hour pH monitoring: Used to diagnose gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), not directly relevant for achalasia unless GERD is also suspected.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Toluidine blue staining is used in the Identification of which of the following cells? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mast Cell

 

Toluidine blue is the special stain for mast cells.

 

Toluidine blue (also known as tolonium chloride) is an acidophilic metachromatic dye that selectively stains acidic tissue components (sulfates, carboxylates, and phosphate radicals). Toluidine blue (TB. has an affinity for nucleic acids, and therefore binds to nuclear material of tissues with a high DNA and RNA content.

 

It also intensely stains some substances leading to a change in color. This effect known as metachromasia.

 

  • Orthochromatic Staining - structures stained blue (Lymphocytes)
  • Metachromatic Staining - structures stained dark purple from polymeric aggregates formed when binding to high concentrations of polyanions (Mast cells)

 

Toluidine blue is often used to identify mast cells by virtue of heparin (which is very polyanionic. found in their secretion granules.

 

 

Application of Toluidine Blue

 

  1. Connective tissue mucins, especially acid mucins. The tissue stains purple to red, while the background is stained blue.
  2. Mast cell granules stain purple in color due to the presence of heparin and histamine.
  3. Amyloid stain blue but under polarized light they give a bright red birefringence.
  4. Endocrine cell granules are stained purple to red.
  5. Sulfatides stain red brown or yellow. Only lipids that are sufficiently acidic to induce a metachromatic shift are stained.
  6. Corynebacterium diphtheria contains granules with polymerized inorganic polyphosphate, which stains red violet color.
  7. Helicobacter stains dark blue against a variably blue background.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphocyte: Lymphocytes can be stained with toluidine blue, but they show orthochromatic staining (blue), not the metachromasia that is characteristic of mast cells.

 

Option B. Fibroblast: Fibroblasts are not specifically identified by toluidine blue staining.

 

Option C. Macrophage: While macrophages can be stained with various dyes, they do not exhibit the metachromasia seen in mast cells with toluidine blue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toluidine blue is primarily used to identify mast cells due to their characteristic metachromatic staining caused by the heparin in their granules.

questions.text: The normal Doppler waveform of the venous blood flow is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Monophasic

 

Explanation:

 

The normal Doppler waveform for venous blood flow is monophasic. This refers to the uniform, steady, and continuous flow pattern typically observed in veins, unlike the varying phases seen in arterial blood flow. Monophasic waveforms indicate a lack of cardiac modulation and resistance, which is characteristic of venous structures that carry blood under lower pressure and with less force than arteries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biphasic: Generally observed in visceral arteries, biphasic waveforms show two distinct directional phases in the blood flow, reflecting the resistance encountered by the blood as it moves through these arteries.

 

 

Option C. Triphasic: This waveform is characteristic of extremity arteries and includes three phases—forward flow, brief reverse flow, and forward flow again, which correspond to the cardiac cycle's effects on arterial blood movement.

 

 

Option D. Absent flow: This is not a normal finding and indicates a blockage or absence of blood flow, which requires further investigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doppler waveforms refer to the morphology of pulsatile blood flow velocity tracings on spectral Doppler ultrasound. 

 

In Doppler ultrasound, the normal venous waveform is monophasic, indicating a steady flow without the complex fluctuations seen in arterial blood flow.

questions.text: Identify the finding associated with the condition shown in the image below which is characterized by development of morphologically similar lesions along the lines of trauma:  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isomorphic phenomenon

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin.
  • The new lesions have iso(same) & morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.

 

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

Darier’s disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, EMF erythema multiforme, Kaposi’s sarcoma & lichen nitidus.

 

Reverse Koebner phenomenon or Renbeok phenomenon:

 

Seen in psoriasis. The area of psoriasis clears & heals following injury (trauma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Gottron's papule seen associated with Dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nikolsky Sign

 

Description: Positive when the superficial epidermis moves laterally with slight rubbing or pressure, leading to the separation of the epidermis from the underlying dermis as shown in the below image.

 

 

 

Option D: Meyerson phenomenon is a melanocytic nevus that has developed an eczematous ring around it as seen in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isomorphic phenomenon (Koebner phenomenon) as the appearance of skin lesions similar to a primary disease along areas of skin trauma, which is important for diagnosis and management in dermatology.

 

References:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 123.2

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with a history of road traffic accident. The axial CT image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extradural Hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image demonstrates a right-sided hyperdense lesion, characteristic of an Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH). Features supporting this diagnosis include:

 

 

Shape and Location: The lesion exhibits a biconvex or "lens-shaped" appearance, typically not crossing sutures, localized at the pterion which is a common site for EDH due to its proximity to the middle meningeal artery (MMA).

 

Type of Trauma: Associated with high-energy trauma such as a road traffic accident, often causing arterial bleeding, specifically from the MMA.

 

Lucid Interval: Patients may experience a lucid interval where symptoms improve temporarily before deteriorating, due to the building pressure from the accumulating blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH): Typically appears as a crescentic or "banana-shaped" collection that can cross sutures but not midline. It arises from bridging veins, often due to lower-energy trauma.

 

Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Usually presents as diffuse or patchy areas of increased density in the subarachnoid spaces, not shown in the image.

 

Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage: Would be visualized within the ventricular system, which is not evident here.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify this sign on USG: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Seashore sign

 

Explanation:


The image shows the "Seashore sign" on M-mode ultrasound, which is used primarily to evaluate for lung sliding. The seashore sign is characterized by a sandy or granular pattern in the lower half of the M-mode display, beneath the pleural line. This pattern is caused by the motion of the lung relative to the pleura during breathing. It is a normal finding, indicating that the lung is sliding smoothly against the parietal pleura, which helps rule out conditions like pneumothorax in the area scanned.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stratosphere sign: Also known as the "barcode sign," it appears as parallel lines in M-mode and is associated with the absence of lung sliding, often seen in cases of pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Lung point sign: This is seen in lung ultrasound as the point at which the normal seashore sign of lung sliding transitions to the stratosphere sign in cases of pneumothorax. It is specific for pneumothorax but not depicted in this ultrasound image.

 

Option D. Sinusoidal sign: Typically refers to a waveform pattern seen in various types of medical imaging and monitoring, not relevant to the depiction of lung sliding on ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung sliding- seen at the pleural lining due to relative motion between pleural layer. Seashore sign- M mode counterpart of lung sliding. Motion of the lung deep to the pleura causes grainy appearance in M-mode, stimulating sand in a seashore.

questions.text: In preterm labor which drug has a neuro-protective role? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MgSO4

 

Explanation:

 

Neuroprotection in preterm labor:

 

  • The drug given is MgSO4.
  • It reduces the incidence of cerebral palsy and neurodevelopmental delay.
  • IV MgSO4 should be offered for neuroprotection of the baby to all women between 24+0 and 29+6 weeks who are:
    • In established preterm labor or
    • Having a planned preterm birth within 24 hours.
  • It can be considered for neuroprotection of the baby for women between 30+0 and 33+6 weeks.
  • Dose: 4 g intravenous bolus of magnesium sulfate over 15 minutes, followed by an intravenous infusion of 1 g per hour until the birth or for 24 hours (whichever is sooner).

 

Uses of MgSO4 in Obstetrics:

 

  1. Treatment of Eclampsia (Anti-seizure)
  2. Prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia (to prevent eclampsia)
  3. As a tocolytic in preterm labor
  4. As a neuroprotective drug in preterm labor (especially < 30 weeks)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nifedipine: A calcium channel blocker used as a tocolytic and antihypertensive but has no role in neuroprotection.

 

Option C. Ritodrine: A beta-sympathomimetic used as a tocolytic but has no neuroprotective role.

 

Option D. Isoxsuprine: Another beta-sympathomimetic used as a tocolytic without neuroprotective properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm labor, MgSO4 is used for neuroprotection, reducing the incidence of cerebral palsy and neurodevelopmental delay in preterm infants.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 538

questions.text: After using a hair dye a lady developed a skin reaction as shown in the image. Which of the following chemicals among given options is responsible for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Para-Phenylenediamine

 

The history of hair dye use and above image points to a diagnosis of contact dermatitis due to an allergen called Para phenylenediamine.

 

Contact Dermatitis is of 2 types:

 

 

Diagnosis of Allergic CD – PATCH TEST

 

Examples of Allergic CD:

 

  1. Hair dye: PPD (para phenylenediamine)
  2. Metal: Nickel (most common)
  3. Topical antibiotic: Neomycin
  4. Cement: Potassium dichromate
  5. Bindi: PTBP (para tertiary butyl phenol)

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pollen:

 

  • Pollen is a common allergen that can cause allergic reactions in some individuals.
  • However, the use of hair dye does not typically involve exposure to pollen, so it is unlikely to be the cause of the skin reaction in this context.

 

Option B. Chromates:

 

  • Chromates, particularly hexavalent chromium compounds, can be found in some industrial processes and certain products.
  • While exposure to chromates can cause skin reactions in some cases, they are not commonly found in hair dyes, so they are less likely to be the cause here.

 

Option C. Balsam of Peru:

 

  • Balsam of Peru is a known allergen found in various cosmetics and fragrance products.
  • It can cause allergic contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
  • If the hair dye contains Balsam of Peru, it could be a potential allergen, but it is not as commonly associated with hair dye allergies as PPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Para-Phenylenediamine (PPD) is a common cause of allergic contact dermatitis (delayed hypersensitivity reaction) associated with hair dye use.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition: 89.73 128.15, 128.42, 128.60

choices.text: Left sided pneumothorax with lung collapse
Rupture of esophagus compressing the pericardium
Flail chest due to fracture of ribs 5, 6, 7 & 8
Normal chest X-ray

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy had bike accident brought by his friends in emergency department with cough, and difficulty in breathing, and chest discomfort. Blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse rate is 88/min, and respiratory rate is 22/min. On auscultation, there is decreased air entry and absent breath sounds on one side. His oxygen saturation is 98% according to the pulse oximeter. Based on the chest X-ray provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?(Aiims November  2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left-sided pneumothorax with lung collapse

 

Explanation:


The Given clinical signs and the chest X-ray findings, the most likely diagnosis is a left-sided pneumothorax with lung collapse. The X-ray would typically show an absence of vascular markings on the left side, indicating the presence of air in the pleural space, and may also show a slight tracheal deviation to the right. The physical examination findings of absent breath sounds and decreased air entry support this diagnosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Rupture of esophagus compressing the pericardium: This is less likely and would typically present with different symptoms, such as severe chest pain and signs of infection or shock.
 

Option C. Flail chest due to fracture of ribs 5, 6, 7 & 8: Flail chest would show paradoxical movement of the chest wall and more severe respiratory distress, which is not suggested in this case.
 

Option D. Normal chest X-ray: The clinical and radiographic findings indicate a significant abnormality, making a normal X-ray an unlikely possibility.

 

Educational Objective:


In a trauma setting, decreased breath sounds and a dark area without vascular markings on the chest X-ray are strong indicators of a pneumothorax with lung collapse, requiring immediate attention
